title: 104_hr2166
content: The "Fairness and Equity Tax Act of 1995" is introduced, which includes a minimum tax on certain foreign and foreign-owned corporations under Subchapter A of chapter 1 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Fairness and Equity Tax Act of 1995" imposes a minimum tax on corporations based on their taxable income from different business activities, ensuring it is at least 90 percent of the applicable profit percentage applied to gross receipts. This applies to domestic corporations that are 25-percent foreign-owned or foreign corporations with gross income. The "Fairness and Equity Tax Act of 1995" imposes a minimum tax on corporations with substantial foreign-related person transactions, excluding those with an approved alternative method by the Secretary for determining taxable income. The "Fairness and Equity Tax Act of 1995" imposes a minimum tax on corporations with substantial foreign-related person transactions, excluding those with an approved alternative method by the Secretary for determining taxable income during the taxable year. The "Fairness and Equity Tax Act of 1995" imposes a minimum tax on corporations with substantial foreign-related person transactions. A qualified section 482 agreement can be entered into between the Secretary and a corporation to ensure a clear reflection of transactions with related parties in any category of business activities. The Secretary can enter into a qualified section 482 agreement with a corporation to reflect taxable income from related party transactions. The agreement may have retroactive effect if deemed necessary by the Secretary. The Secretary may apply a qualified section 482 agreement retroactively to prior taxable years if deemed necessary, regardless of when the agreement is in effect. If a corporation's activities cannot be categorized by the Secretary based on Standard Industrial Classification Codes, an exception applies. In cases where a corporation's activities cannot be categorized by the Secretary based on Standard Industrial Classification Codes, a minimum tax of 35 percent is imposed on gross receipts from property sales or leases. The tax code imposes a minimum tax of 35 percent on gross receipts from property sales or leases, excluding certain circumstances like casualties or disasters. Foreign taxes are not considered in determining taxable income. The tax code imposes a minimum tax of 35 percent on property sales or leases, excluding certain circumstances like casualties or disasters. For purposes of this section, taxable income is determined without considering foreign taxes paid. The Secretary prescribes an applicable profit percentage for each category of business activities for taxable years beginning in the calendar year specified. The tax code imposes a minimum tax of 35 percent on property sales or leases, excluding certain circumstances like casualties or disasters. The Secretary prescribes an applicable profit percentage for each category of business activities based on average earnings rates of domestic corporations. The tax code imposes a minimum tax of 35 percent on property sales or leases, excluding certain circumstances like casualties or disasters. The earnings rate of any domestic corporation for a category of business activities is based on the ratio of adjusted book income to gross receipts. Adjusted book income is income reported for financial purposes without reductions for income, war profits, or excess profits taxes. The term 'adjusted book income' refers to income reported for financial purposes without reductions for income, war profits, or excess profits taxes imposed by the US, any US possession, or any foreign country. Definitions and special rules include terms like '25-percent foreign-owned', 'foreign person', and 'related party'. The term '25-percent foreign-owned', 'foreign person', and 'related party' have specific meanings under section 6038A(c). A corporation has substantial foreign-related person transactions if the total amount with foreign related parties exceeds $2,000,000 or 10% of the corporation's gross income for the year. Transactions with related parties who are foreign persons during the taxable year must not exceed $2,000,000 or 10% of the corporation's gross income. Business activities are categorized based on the 3-digit Standard Industrial Classification Code. The Secretary has the authority to aggregate multiple classifications when necessary. The Secretary has the authority to categorize business activities based on the 3-digit Standard Industrial Classification Code and may aggregate multiple classifications when appropriate. A clerical amendment is made to the table of parts for subchapter A of chapter 1 of the Code. Effective Date: The amendments apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 1995.
